A very rich site and despite the amount of people, it still maintains a sacred atmosphere.  A must-see for those passing through this city.

column8: An impressive ancient monument in the heart of the Palace Complex, Polonnaruwa.
column11: Vadatage is impressive even after lying in ruins for almost a thousand years. One of the major archaeological sites, Polonnaruwa, Sri Lanka has many monuments located close to each other in the palace complex which sound almost similar. The moon stone at the entrance is intricately carved and is clearly visible even after all these centuries. The buddha statues still retain their radiance even after almost a thousand years. It is said that the name comes from the round shape of the Buddhist Shrine. A must visit while you are in Polonnaruwa, Sri Lanka. Recommended.

column8: A Perfect Circle of Ancient Beauty
column11: Polonnaruwa Vatadage was one of the highlights of my visit to Sri Lanka. Many people rush through Polonnaruwa and completely miss this spot, but it’s honestly one of the most beautiful ruins I’ve seen. It’s a circular stone shrine over 800 years old, with beautiful carvings, stone steps, and small Buddha statues around the center. The craftsmanship is incredible, and you can feel how important and sacred this place was in ancient times. One important thing to know: you can’t go inside with shoes or slippers, so definitely bring a pair of socks if you want to explore it comfortably! The stone floor can be hot under the sun. I love how peaceful it felt. Even with other tourists around, there’s something calming about walking slowly around the circle, admiring the carvings and imagining what it looked like centuries ago. If you love history, architecture, or just discovering hidden gems, don’t skip the Vatadage when you visit Polonnaruwa! Tip: Go early morning or late afternoon for the best light and fewer crowds.

part of a collection of budist sites in the sacred city  of pollonnaruwa this is perhaps one of the better ones.  You'll need to be Budist or have a good guide book to understand everything, otherwise you are just missing out

We were quite glad we had come in a car and could have AC.  It was very hot and we forgot to bring our socks, so our feet were very hot.  You do have to remove hat and shoes.  Some great details to take a close look at and the museum did cover what a lot of them meant which we found interesting.  A good half day trip from Sigiriya.

column8: One of the ancient capitals of Sri Lanka
column11: Atmospheric and interesting in terms of Sri Lanka's historical heritage. Polonnaruwa is one of the ancient capitals. A few secular and religious structures remain here, but all but a few of them are scattered over a large area, so it is possible to move on foot, but early in the morning, then the sun bakes mercilessly. Most visitors travel by tuk-tuk and bike, although I have seen buses. The ticket office is located next to the museum and it is a few kilometers from the entrance. Ticket $30, you can map, give a paper site map in English, well of course, if you need a guide asked. There are Russian speakers who need to. Someone comparing it to Angkor is a very big exaggeration.

column8: Very interesting and scenic, lots of history
column11: Lots of ruins to walk around with useful written guides (as well as our tour guide). Lots of history and a huge site, so was helpful that also driven at times, though could be waked with more time.
This is my favorite of the Polonnaruwa ruins. It is particularly famous for its unique circular architecture, but it is also a must-see with a variety of interesting buildings around it.

column8: You can still breathe its sacredness
column11: The Sacred Quadrilateral is the center of the sacredness of the ancient capital. Among the different buildings, in which you have to move barefoot and with covered legs, the Vatadage stands out, where a sacred relic of the Buddha was kept. The decorations, the layout of the structure, declined according to the four cardinal points, the sacredness, which still breathes despite the many tourists, make it one of the most significant points of the visit to Polonnaruwa.

It is definitely one of the visits to do if you are going to Sri Lanka because in this place you will find history and some really very beautiful and significant monuments. Obviously if you decide to shoot the place, use vehicles because they are far from each other and above all arrive prepared because otherwise you will not appreciate their real meaning.

Polonnaruwa became the capital of the Sinhalese kingdom after Anuradhapura, and remained so for three centuries. The archaeological area is very vast, it includes ruins of the Royal Palace, the quadrilateral area (Vatadage) with many brick temples covered in moss. Finally Lankatilaka Temples (high walls without roofs) and Gal Vitara, with more rock sculptures of sitting, standing and reclining Buddha. Spectacular!!
Impressive, wonderful ruins, a must-see, you will surely like it, take it easy and enjoy what you see.

Still standing after nearly a thousand years or more. The moonstones speaks volumes on their own! The statues are incredible. Of course they could have been maintained better but glad there is still some remains left of the ancient Polonaruwa Dynasty. Evidence that it must have been a very rich monarchy all those centuries ago ! Definitely worth a visit if in the region.

The round Buddha temple is still standing even after almost a thousand years. This temple could possibly have been used exclusively by the royal family. The Buddha statues facing the cardinal directions glimmer even in the dark. The paintings are long gone and the ornate walls have become bare but the charm and quiet of the vihara endure. The moonstone depicting the various phases of human life is exquisitely carved in granite. Located in the Royal Complex, A must visit while you are in Pulanaruva, Sri Lanka.

A great great Historical Monument which must be visited during your visit to the World heritage Site of Polonnaruwa Ancient City where proves the greater Development of my Singhalese Nation Consisted with Art, Technology, Attitudes, Cultural Backgrounds, Traditions, Technotraditions, International Relations and Royal Patronage by the 10th Century AD!
Polonnaruwa vatadage is most famous and ancient place in Sri Lanka.it was a superb place to see tradition of kingdom of polonnaruwa.it's an amazing archeological treasure.

The history says this site is an ancient tooth relic shrine of Buddha ? All  I know is that it is a fabulous survivor of days long gone. The site still holds religious tenets and all are required to remove their shoes to enter. While I found the ruins to be pretty special , the vibe was lowered by the multitude of touts trying to sell tourist items ! Very annoying and detracts from the ancient city feeling !!

This is one of the most preserved ruins from the Polonnaruwa Kindom, built since 12th century. It is believed to be a sacred site that hold the relic of Buddha. Vatadage is a Buddhist structure typically built in Sri Lanka during the ancient times to enshrine the relic of Buddha with circular shape and built of stone or bricks with elaborated stone carvings. The architecture is believed to have influence of Hinduism culture. We particularly love the carvings at the entrance of the staircase and the well-known moon stone carvings at the foot of the first flight of step which usually made at a Buddhist architecture. Remarkable masterpiece in the ancient world of Polonnaruwa!
Came here on our bikes, most convenient way to go next to a car. Loved the old ruïnes and it wasn’t to crowded with people
Interesting but by this time  we were suffering from ruins overkill! Quite busy, there were quite a number of people selling tacky souvenirs which we avoided.

Polonnaruwa vatadage is a most famous  location in Polonnaruwa area. It is consisting with more ancient valuable with old Buddhism civilization and old architecture of in those area. It has made with bricks and stones. It is a better place to see traditions of kingdom of Polonnaruwa.
Some very different structures to explore here and a fascinating history.  Glad I visited and was pretty well free of other tourists in late afternoon (most tours visit here in the morning).

Some amazing craftsmanship and architecture. Come on a weekday if you wanna enjoy the palace in a crowed free environment. Can take photos. Make sure you wear something that covers you fully that goes below your knees. A wrap would do if you can't bare the heat.

The circular relic house is the most fascinating structure here. Its steps are aligned to the cardinal points. Beyond these steps are stone Buddhas, sitting on a dais, crosslegged. It has an excellent moonstone [northern entrance]. It was likely built by Parakramabahu but Nissankamalla tried to claim credit for it in the Gal Pota, the nearby stone book. It likely held the Tooth Relic at one time. If the Quadrangle is the heart of Polonnuwara the Vatadage is the heart of the Quadrangle.
An amazing archeological treasure. Beautiful carvings and an incredible structure from 800 years ago
As you move around Polonnaruwa, you are just left wondering....how did the folks of ancient folks build these marvelous structures?

Nice ancient city with Buddhist statues One of the sites within the Polonnaruwa Archaelogical Site. Located outside the main building, this is where each of the 3 great kings built these Buddhist temples. To take a closer look, one has to remove shoes and hats.

Circular Relic Chamber is the term to call this holistic, historic place. Built by King Parakramabahu the Great , the chamber housed "The Sacred Tooth Relic". There was a roof on top of the structure. With time it has been destroyed. Still a panoramic location one must not miss while visiting Sri Lanka.

One of the nicer spots within the whole precinct. Very near to panoramic Parakrama Samudraya. If you are here, can also eat and chill at the very hospitable place Ekho Lake House. Highly recc! Also do not step on the sides of the structure, stick to the main footpaths.

This is a world heritage site of great beauty and interest.  The site is well preserved and maintained and contains a number of historic remains most of which are intricately carved with beautiful designs, symbols, images and intricate scenes. As so often happens at these historic sites one marvels at the beauty of these ancient monuments and finds it difficult to imagine them in all their glory when they were intact, gilded and highly decorated.
It was a very hot day when we visited. Very well preserved ruins. Guide was hit and miss, depending on your luck. Make sure you pair your visit with the nearby archaeological museum.

It is believed that the Polonnaruwa Vatadage was built during the reign of Parakramabahu 1 to hold the Relic, the Tooth of the Buddha. It is an elevated structure, a Sandakada Pahana located at the base of the stairs that leads to the first terrace. The inner and outer walls are adorned with various friezes and other designs. The four entrances to the upper terrace are adorned with stone carvings: moonstones flanked by nagaraja figures with cobra head guard-stones. The Tooth Relic was kept in the small brick stupa that still exists. Wonderful history.
It's an ancient structure in the history of Sri Lanka which belongs to the Polonnaruwa kingdom; the second kingdom of Sri Lanka. Its unique architectural structure is awesome.
Very important  and most hestiycal place. We are very like. Lost Sri Lankan people came their and vership.

This is a world heritage site and a must visit in Polonnaruwa. Well preserved site. Built for the protection of a small stupa, the structure has two stone platforms decorated with elaborate stone carvings. The upper platform, surrounded by a brick wall, contains the stupa. Four Buddha statues are seated around it, each facing one of the entrances.

The stone engravings here outline the history in a language still used so the guides can tell you exactly how it was built etc. Only 40% has been excavated so far and it is already huge. The site was preserved by a build up of soil over hundreds of years so 8mtrs had to be dug out to show the buildings.. we biked it from one end to the other which made it fun. A good museum starts your visit. Definitely worth a visit to understand Sri Lanka’s history
Very interesting archaeological site, if you like Chichen Itza in Mexico Site is spread out over quite a large area so bike is a good option.
I would rate this better than Anuradhapurra - also nice - but here the details of the stone carvings are so good! Did I mention cold king coconuts - its probably my favorite thing about Sri Lanka!

Several areas and they are in different states of restauration/repair. Start at the North site, where the 4 Buddhas are. Then leisurely stroll back and spend your dayat Polonnaruwa. There are 2 places on the way back to the entrance where you can buy refreshments. The most disappointing part was the one around the museum (and the museum itself) as well as the "Mausoleum" also on the other side of the road. We gave up on the bicycle idea and took a tuktuk to the Buddhas, then walked back.

Polunnaruwa ruins comprise of a number of different areas and the vatadage is one of the must see spots within the wider world heritage site. The vatadage is very well preserved stupa with four statues of buddha. Around the vatadage, in the Dalada Maluva quadrangle, are a fascinating number of different ruins, some of which you have to take your shoes off for. Make sure to take a pair of socks, to protect your feet from the pebbles and hot floor. Expect it to be busy, so try to come early or late in the day.

With visitors as it use to house the Buddhas tooth, (which is now in candy), there was a big group of worshippers in attendance during our visit which just added to the atmosphere. it was a nice place just to walk around, no shoes for those who want to go inside, we recommend socks, especially on a hot day.

Another part of the extensive Polonnaruwa archaeological site that was covered over for many centuries before being discovered I'm told in the late 1800s to early 1900s. The Vatadage is a combo of beautiful decorated carved stonework that has many Buddha statues within. To enter you must remove your shoes, though there didn't appear to be similar restrictions on dress code. Be aware that the stone surface gets very hot on bare feet so it's advisable to visit early in the day if the forecast is for high temperatures.
This relic house is at the heart of Polonnaruwa's quadrangle.  It is dramatic and elegant - and beautiful.  Dont miss it if you visit the site

I loved this place coz it was really a piece of art, but the bothering thing was you have to take off your shoes and go there and because of hot floor i just can stand for a minute but some people can stand the hot floor and go inside.
This is a wonderful site even though it has been damaged over the ages by weather  and perhaps others.

To fully appreciate this area, a local guide is essential. This is just one of the religious sites that formerly housed the Buddha tooth relic (now in Kandy). Mentioned by many, but as a visitor you must bare your head & feet & cover your knees. Take socks or expect burnt soles. This particular Temple site is impressive.

Amazing place! First we visited museum (included in the entrance fee: 25$ for adult and 12,5$ for child) and then we rent a bike (500 rupees per bike). Although it was insanely hot, it’s defiantly one of the top places in Sri Lanka. Recommend! On the way back to Dambulla we met elephant beside main road.
Just walking around admiring and trying to contemplate what tools could possibly have been used to create such edifices

Built by Parakramabahu-I, this is a circular relic house which is said to have formerly housed the Sacred Tooth Relic of the Buddha. The building consisted of two concentric terraces including an upper terrace on which was placed a chetiya in which the Sacred Tooth Relic was placed.
Each temple complex requires you to remove your shoes and the stone floors are incredibly hot.  Perhaps wear trainer socks to make it more bearable.  The temple are itself is exquisite.

What an amazing site. Part of the old Temples in the second oldest kingdom in Sri Lanka. This has four openings which each has a Buddha statue faceing outwards and down a flight of stairs. Absolutely stunning and beautiful. A must see.

The ruins of Polonnaruwa are spread over several different sites, entry was 9600 rupees which covered all the sites. Do not pay what you are asked for souvenirs here, we were offered a buddha for $6 that came down to $1 when we showed no interest. The ruins as they are ruins vary greatly so some will be more interesting than others. We did find other places that we visited more interesting because of this.

The best part about this particular attraction is that there are at least 5 sites to see within close proximity to each other.  You can see most of the Vatadage by walking around the perimeter without removing your shoes.  There are some nice carvings in the stones that are worth looking at.
Really good part of Sri Lankan history, enjoyable to listen to the guide explaining everything. well worth a visit

it is a structure that is more or less unique to the architecture of ancient Sri Lanka. Vatadages were built around small stupas for their protection, which often enshrined a relic. Circular in shape, they were commonly built of stone and brick and adorned with elaborate stone carvings.So whatever other photos may be on here, unless its the circular building or the inner stupa, the photo will be of other adjacent structures.
This place is very well preserved. Is is a must see in Polonnaruwa. I think a guide is needed, so that you will get the information about the places were you are.
On tourist maps I think this is an area referred to as the quadrangle. Each sight is still considered active religious, so you have to take off your shoes.

The ruins itself are beautiful to see and most of them are still act as working temples so you are required to cover your legs (men and women) and the shoulders for ladies. No shoes or hats are allowed either, which can be a bit difficult for small children or elderly as the temperature in Polannaruwa reaches up to 40 degrees Celsius and the sand and the stones are usually boiling hot. Also please be aware of the amount of people who will be targeting tourists to sell all sort of mementos (Please feel free to bargain and don't pay the first price). Also take a lot of water with you as it's very very hot!

An amazing historic site - easily walked if you like you can hire a bike. Like many tourist attractions in Sri Lanka the foreigners prices are steep and all toddlers must be purchased at the museum where you will be inundated with guides - just say no (you need to be firm) as they charge like wounded bulls and can add very little to the information in the guide maps ...

By the time you've reached this site among the many ruins in the area, you may think that you've had enough.  But do NOT overlook this site.  It ranks among the most impressive ruins you'll see here. It has far more variety of structures surrounding the well preserved stupa, including the 2nd most impressive moonstone in all of Sri Lanka. Even without the history underlying the site, you can easily spend an hour here for the numerous photo ops on the grounds. There IS a reason that this area is now among UNESCO World Heritage sites.

A vatadage is a type of Buddhist structure, typical for Sri Lanka and usually build around a small stupa. Considered to be the best preserved and the most elaborate example of a vatadage in the country, Polonnaruwa Vatadage has two stone platforms decorated with elaborate stone carvings. The circular lower platform is entered through a single entrance on the northern side and is endowed with a nicely carved moonstone. Four elaborately constructed doorways facing the four cardinal points lead to the upper platform which contains the stupa and is surrounded by a brick wall on its edge.  Four Buddha statues are seated around it, each facing one of the entrances. It is one of the best preserved and most beautiful ruins you're going to see in the country and is not to be missed..

The structure is quite impressive in current ruined state and must have been very beautiful, had it been intact. It is a circular, multilevel structure, with entrance from four direction. All the entrances have Buddha statues facing out words. The structure is believed to be built in 12th Century. The site provides good photo opportunities. The site is unmissable when visiting the Heritage City of Polonnaruwa.

These are medieval buildings of Polonnaruwa which is quite amazing dating back to 8th Centuries. We had a private guide and started at the museum where we could see the original replicas. Entrance to all sites cost 18000 for 5 of us
Great ruins that are still able to entice your imagination with images in your mind. incredible history behind these magnificent buildings.
Great ruins that are still able to make your imagination paint pictures in your mind. Fantastic history behind the buildings. Get a good speaking guide , they are really cheap  but essential.

Great place to visit. Lots of ruins and information. You really need some sort of transport to get around, tuk-tuk is fine. Also preferably wear socks as you will need to take off your shoes to enter some areas and the ground can be very hot and/or stony.

It's one of the most beautiful archeological sites I've seen around the world. So big that you can't do it by foot, bycycles recommended :) (I'd say 10 times bigger than Pompéï in Italy). Really great place.

Please visit the museum to understand the real time structure of this. Most of the wooden part of the structure have been destroyed what is remaining here is mostly stone made There are four Samadhi Buddha statues that displays the Sri Lankan craftmanship

This ancient ruin is the highlight of this sacred site.  Of course, the higher floors and roof are long gone, but it is still possible to imagine what a magnificent building this had once been. The circular style and four compass-point entrances are a very interesting style and featured carvings are beautiful. Must be visited.

Walking around the ruins here is an amazing experience. We were lucky enough to visit late afternoon making photography opportunities richer die to the light. Loved the history. Loved the architecture. Go.

The entire sacred site of Polonnaruwa is absolutely awe inspiring but the Vatadage is probably is crowning glory in my opinion. It's a stunning place built originally to house the Buddha Tooth Relic that now rests in Kandy. It has a main entrance with an ornate moonstone and once inside that there is a second upper level with four evenly spaced entrances each facing North, Siuth, Eas and West with a Buddha statue facing you. It would have had a giant roof which has not survived and under that was the stupa that housed the relic. It's hard to believe that excavations only began in 1903 given its age but the statues are amazingly well preserved and/or restored. The four Buddha's are striking and the ornate staircase and supplementary statuary are awesome. We stayed for quite a while here entranced by the beauty of the place. Completely mesmerising. You will need to cover shoulders and knees and remove shoes but socks are allowerd and indeed essential given how hot the sun bakes the stones underfoot.

I visited the sacred city in April with a Dutch group and was impressed by the size of the complex, which consists of three parts: Dalada Maluwa, Dalada Malawu and the royal citadel and castle - all very impressive.
This place along with Galvihara and Siva Devalayas are highlights of Polannaruwa. This beautiful piece of art and whole area(Polonnaruwa) requires minimum 4 hours of dedicated time.
Religious place and Please be good. Remove your shoes and hats before entering.Watch out for monkeys as they will grab your things and fly to trees
An amazing historic complex with any number of ancient buildings. This is worth every effort to go and visit!
This is a good part of the large site and school groups come and go so you get some clear photos! The carving is fine but the history info a bit scanty buy a good book first.
This is a site worth visiting and walking around and viewing from various angles and you can walk into it minus shoes.
located in polonnaruwa ,this place has 4 buddha statues in center which show cases the Buddhist heritage from ages in the kingdom, The ruins are well preserved. a must visit location
Located in ancient polonnaruwa kingdom infront of parakrama lake. Many things to see. Great buddhist heritage.
This building must be visited as it is said to have held the relic of the tooth in ancient times.  It is a covered stupa and has wonderful carvings and statues.

The site has many well preserved ruins, some of them indicating the full glory and beauty of the ancient town. The whole area is relatively big, be prepared to walk few hours to see all parts of the site.
Another site within Polonnaruwa, where the legend is the tooth and bowl of Bhudda was kept. Again getting a guide is important.

Then you have a good idea of the ancient city and can enjoy a bike tour You can get to the shop and washroom (such at Sigiryia) without ticket Same advice there If you could visit the museum before the visit that ideal, but the ideal is also to be in the park at the coolest hours early morning It is worth a few hours I paid a guide but was pretty disapointed for the price

Another of my favorite ruins in Polonnaruwa, the Vatadage has some beautiful seated Buddhas.  Travel note:  since you have to take off your shoes, wear socks.  The stone floors get really hot in the noon day sun.
The Polonnaruwa Vatadage is simply a must see with all its statues/scultures and the detail depicted on each.

Worth a visit during the Polonnaruwa ruins tour. Make sure to remove your shoes and have your shoulders and knees covered if you want to enter. The famous sandakada pahana on each entrance is worth seeing for the work done on them. Because of the history involved (some suggest that it was built for holding the sacred tooth relic), this is very interesting place to see.

Seriously suggest you do this with a guide, the history and background to the place and some of the buildings is truly fascinating. I would recommend 2-3 hours, there is so much to see. Note: Take water and sunblock or an umbrella on hot days, there is limited shade.

As the ancient city goes I liked this one most. You have to climb on a small plateau where you find a few temples and old palaces. I liked this one so much because it did not feel like a ruin, it is well preserved, all carvings seem fresh. It also has a different shape then the rest, very decorated, looks like it was built with no roof

This is another interesting ruin at Polonnaruwa. We had to remove our shoes to enter and cover our shoulders and knees. Our guide explained the ruins and the history of this place. Well worth getting a guide.

This structure, dated back in to polonnaruwa era 1000 years back is one of the excellent monuments showing ancient technological advancement as well as the proud culture of the sri lankan. A must see place if you’re visiting sri lanka.

A visit through the Polonnaruwa Ruins would not be complete with seeing the impressive ruins at Polonnaruwa Vatadage. I was blessed that my tour guide partnered with a guide he recommended I pay for, the guide used to work in the Archaeological Department.  And I am so glad I did!  The ruins themselves, without the historical stories and explanations would be simply that - ruins. Take the time to read everything available, ask questions, respect the dress codes and take it all in.  It was my favourite experience in Sri Lanka.
This is a old Buddhist temple. You need about half an hour here. Worth the visit.You will not miss it on your walk around the ruins.

Must visit the Vatadage in Polonnaruwa. The moonstone is a beautiful piece of stone carving. We did a hald-day stop at Polonnaruwa and this was not enough. The ruins are extensive and spread out over some acres. So, we hired cycles to get around and this took time. We saw some beautiful, old ruins that were well-preserved.

Excellent examples of the early settlement are here . Great remains of several temples and other buildings are found here. To get into most of them you need to take shoes off and cover up appropriately. There are custodians that will remind you if you forget. This is a beautiful perfect stupa which has its charm. It is even more remarkable to know that the Tooth Relic was once kept here. There are 2 places like these in Sri Lanka .and they are Polonnaruwa and Meditigiriya. Most beautiful Vatadage is found in Medirigiriya. ‘Vatadage’ means Circular house for the tooth. It is one of the many ancient monuments in Polonnaruwa, excellent craftsmanship are observed at the statues and the carvings all around this site.  This is one of the most wonderful architecture of the ancient civilization. It is definitely a place that every visitor has to visit. Although an inscription records says, this beautiful stupa house has been built before the time of the King Nissanka Nalla, he has carried out major renovations on this building. The uniqueness of such buildings is that the stupa is protected by a roof.  On the centre there is a small stupa and on the four sides, there are beautiful carved Lord Buddha statues. These statues are different as normally they are found with the curly hair and here, a  snot is visible on the head and the robe is also flat which is unusual.  The roof has been supported by two rows of stone pillars around the stupa though none of them are visible today. However, the pillars outside the walls are still intact. Four sets of beautifully carved stone stairs lead to the upper levels from four sides. on the sides of stair case some of the most beautiful guard stones and moon stones are seen in this here an tradition of its era. The guard stone of the eastern side of the temple are said to be the best guard stone in the Polonnaruwa era. There are rotunda shape freaky dwarf figures for the protection of these buildings. Located in the southeast is the Quadrangle or "Dalada Maluwa" decorated with elaborate stone carvings Here you will see a very good example of a Moon Stone and some excellent releif work the entrance to the central Dagaba accessible without removing shoes. If hot and sunny, bring some socks as the stone floor will burn your feet. Otherwise it is a great place to visit. This whole site is incredible and a wonder of the ancient world. Touring the whole site in a day is the best way to see the places and even better if you have a good guide that can explain everything. I recommend you to visit Polonnaruwa Vatadage.

We had a day stop in Polonnaruwa, this is not enough. Let me begin with that. The ruins of palaces and other heritage buildings in Polonnaruwa would take you a atleast 3 to 4 days to relax and enjoy if you are a history and architect enthusiast. I think it is important to spend time in the museum before starting to explore the heritage buildings of Polonnaruwa. The reseach stories here will help you understand the ruins and the glory of the place. Some people had hired bicycles to look around the places which I would recommend as it looked like a very sensible thing to do. It was very hot in May adding to that was the heat from granite stone floors. You are not allowed to wear sandals/ shoes so it is best you plan your visit avoiding afternoon time maybe 12 to 2. Rest is for you to go and enjoy :)
A slightly more interesting ruin with lion statues guarding the 4 directional staircases. On top are 4 sitting Buddhas and several columns and brick walls. Not really impressive. Rather common

Polonnaruwa Vatadage is believed to have been built during the reign of Parakramabahu I to hold the Relic of the tooth of the Buddha. This is the most beautiful structure in Polonnaruwa for photography. The best time for photography is after 4PM since the sun comes in side view to the structure and you will get very smooth warm-coloured light on the subject. As well do not forget to bring a wide Wide-angle lens there !!!!!

This area you cannot ride a bike in. You can ride your bike to the area but  I not inside. You needed to remove your shoes to enter the ancient areas with Buddha. There are a lot of interesting facts you should check out online and at the sites (these areas hold a lot of history behind them). Remember it is very disrespectful to take pictures of Buddha and to take a picture with your back to him. You can take a picture in some areas and never face fully away; from your side or you face Buddha. This area was once from an ancient city where the light lived. You can see old walls, areas where people used to pray, areas where people used to do scribing and so on. The entrance ticket covers three different places: Archeological Museum, Lankathilaka Image House, and Gal Vihara (I recommend doing them in this order). The price: 3350 rupees per person. Buy tickets at the museum.

Polonnaruwa Vatadage is another ancient construction which depicts talent possessed by Sri Lankan people back in the day. It is a structure that would keep the buddha statues and small temples safe. There are only ten Vatadages remaining in country and Polonnaruwa Vatadage is the most famous one. This is a unique architectural structure in Sri Lanka and a must visit by both locals and foreigners
Another, of the multitude, of well preserved cultural sites going back 2000.  The skill of Sri Lankan's is incredible.  Revered by locals & visitors alike. Excellent!

This is a part of the Sacred Quadrangle or Royal Palace. It has a beautiful circular wall around the structure, the roof of which no more exists. beautiful Buddha statue is within this and has the famous moonstone at the start of the steps leading into the structure. Historically believed to have built to hold the tooth relic.

The Polonnaruwa Vatadage is an ancient structure dating back to the Kingdom of Polonnaruwa of Sri Lanka. It is believed to have been built during the reign of Parakramabahu I to hold the Relic of the tooth of the Buddha or during the reign of Nissanka Malla of Polonnaruwa to hold the alms bowl used by the Buddha. Both these venerated relics would have given the structure a great significance and importance at the time. Located within the ancient city of Polonnaruwa, it is the best preserved example of a vatadage in the country, and has been described as the "ultimate development" of this type of architecture. Abandoned for several centuries, excavation work at the Polonnaruwa Vatadage began in 1903.
